Jonathon Manning Newcastle law firm Bond Dickinson ranked 16th for brand recognition 
Bond Dickinson has been named as having one of the top 20 UK law firm brands, after being ranked 16th in the Acritas UK Law Firm Brand Index 2017. 
The position is two higher than last year when the firm tanked 18th. 
The report is based on data collected between January and November 2016 and ranks a total of 163 law firms. 
Launched on May 3, the report measures performance of law firms across key criteria such as: top of mind awareness, favourability, and consideration for top level litigation and M&A. 
Jonathan Blair, managing partner at Bond Dickinson, said: 
We’ve worked hard to keep developing a strong brand as a national firm and are delighted to feature amongst the Top 20 in the Acritas UK Law Firm Brand Index. It’s good to see that Bond Dickinson is a brand that clients associate with excellent service and heavyweight legal expertise. Jonathan Blair, managing partner of Bond Dickinson 9:12 Jonathon Manning KPMG facing watchdog probe after Rolls-Royce finances Audit 
Britain’s accountancy watchdog has opened an investigation into KPMG’s audit of Rolls- Royce after the engine-maker agreed to pay £671m to settle bribery and corruption claims. 
The Financial Reporting Council (FRC) said it will probe the conduct of the accountancy giant in relation to the audit of the financial statements of Rolls-Royce for 2010, 2011 and 2013. 
The decision to investigate follows a Deferred Prosecution Agreement between Rolls-Royce and the Serious Fraud Office in January, which saw the firm stump up £671m to settle corruption and bribery allegations. 
The FRC said: 
The FRC has commenced an investigation under the Audit Enforcement Procedure into the conduct of KPMG Audit Plc, in relation to the audit of the financial statements of Rolls-Royce Group plc for the year ended 31 December 2010 and of Rolls-Royce Holdings plc for the years ended 31 December 2011 to 31 December 2013. 
The decision to investigate follows the SFO announcement on 17 January 2017 of a Deferred Prosecution Agreement between the SFO and Rolls-Royce which relates to offences including conspiracy to corrupt and a failure to prevent bribery. 
The agreements relate to bribery and corruption scandals involving intermediaries in overseas markets such as Indonesia and China. Rolls-Royce first passed information to the SFO in 2012 after facing “allegations of malpractice” in the two countries, after which the fraud squad launched a formal investigation. 
Officials for the firm, which has an office in Newcastle, said at the time its own investigations had found “matters of concern” in additional overseas markets. KPMG offices (Photo: Niall Carson/PA Wire) 9:04 KEY EVENT Accounting change sends HSBC profits 19% lower 
Profits at HSBC fell 19% in the first quarter after an accounting change hit the banking giant’s bottom line. 
The British lender said the fall to $5bn (£3.8bn) reflected a change in the accounting of the fair value of its debt. However, the figure was still ahead of expectations, and adjusted pre-tax profits rose 12% to $5.9bn (£4.5bn) as the bank was boosted by improved trading and rising interest rates. 
Adjusted revenue edged 2% higher to 12.8bn (£9.9bn), helped by growth in current accounts, savings and deposits. The bank’s London-listed shares rose 3.3% in morning trading as investors welcomed the figures. 
Chief executive Stuart Gulliver said: 
This is a good set of results. The increase in adjusted profit was driven by strong performances in three of our four global businesses. 
Global banking and markets had a great quarter, commercial banking delivered higher revenue from our liquidity and cash management activities, and retail banking and wealth management was supported by rising interest rates and renewed customer investment appetite. 
Mr Gulliver also flagged progress on HSBC’s cost-cutting programme, through which it aims to save around $6bn(£4.8bn) a year. 
The results came after the bank revealed in February that it was facing a UK investigation over money-laundering controls and posted a worse-than-expected 62% full-year profits slump. 
The lender said the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) launched a probe at the end of last year into its financial crime compliance, with the group remaining under pressure on both sides of the Atlantic after its £1.2nn US money-laundering fine nearly five years ago. 
HSBC is one of a number of banks considering relocating jobs to the continent after the Brexit vote, having said that 1,000 jobs may have to move from London to Paris over the next two years depending on the outcome of negotiations. 
The trading update was the first since HSBC revealed that AIA chief executive Mark Tucker will replace outgoing chairman Douglas Flint in October. A sign outside a HSBC branch (Photo: Joe Giddens/PA Wire) 8:55 KEY EVENT More than 120 jobs lost at North Shields furniture maker Hobart Rose 
More than 120 jobs have been lost at a North East furniture maker after the firm lost a major client. 
Fuda International Trading Company, which traded as Hobart Rose, produced furniture and soft furnishings for the likes of Dunelm, John Lewis and Next from its North Shields base. It also ran a popular factory outlet shop. 
However, the long-established family firm has ceased to trade with the loss of the entire 122-strong workforce after running into financial issues following the loss of a major contract. 
A statement issued on behalf of the firm told how the directors were unable to come to repayment agreements with creditors and unfortunately had no option other than to close the doors. 
The company’s affairs are now being dealt with by accountancy firm Tait Walker. 
Established around 58 years ago, Hobart Rose used to run an operation in China with two other local partners, which employed 150 people, but recent years had seen the firm make efforts to reshore jobs. 
Only two years ago it was announced that the furniture manufacturer had managed to reshore around 20% of its manufacturing back from China and that it expected to create 100 jobs in the process. 
The North Shields-based firm used funding from the Manufacturing Advisory Service (MAS) to make the move and it also received around £285,000 investment from The Journal’s Let’s Grow fund to help to equip the firm, along with support from the Business Growth Service. 
The firm’s last accounts, for the year ended April 30 2016, showed that moves to “home-shore” was going as planned, but that trading conditions remained tough throughout the last year, Brexit was challenging margins and there was a significant reduction in sales in the run-up to the crucial Christmas trading period. 
In a review of the business, filed at companies house on January 27 2017, directors described how a reorganisation at its main customer led to a drop in sales, which slipped from £8.4m to £7.15m. The previous year’s operating profit of £63,432 also dropped to a loss of £127,061. From left: Martin Robinson, David Rose (both Fuda Hobart Rose Ltd) and Cameron Ross (MAS) back in 2015 when the firm was tapping into funding to bring work back to the North East (Photo: tark archive) 8:50 Jonathon Manning Northgate Vehicle hire places £2.5m order for new pick-up truck 
Northgate Vehicle Hire has placed an order worth £2.5m for a fleet of Isuzu D-Max pick-up trucks on the day of its launch. 
The previous version of the truck has proved popular within the hire company’s 50,000-strong fleet of vehicles. 
Eddie Aston, managing director at Northgate Vehicle Hire, said: 
The new D-Max vehicle is a better proposition than ever. Not only has it retained its 3.5 tonne towing capability, it also has no AdBlue, better fuel economy and lower CO2 emissions than the earlier version. 
As a business, Northgate seeks to provide the best vehicle in each category. Isuzu certainly ticks the box in the pick-up sector 
Northgate is the largest buyer of commercial vehicles in the UK. It supplies cars, vans, pick-up trucks and other specialised vehicles to the commercial market. Bob Contreras, chief executive of Northgate plc 8:44 Jonathon Manning Stadium Group boast increased order book and find new FD 
Hartlepool-based Stadium Group has revealed its order book has increased by £2.2m since the year end. 
Chairman Nick Brayshaw will tell investors, at the group’s AGM today, that the company’s order book now exceeds £28m. This is up from £25.8m at the year end. 
The firm has also ended its search for a new finance director after Joanne Estell stepped down in October last year. She was due to be replaced by Rex Orton, but he was unable to take up the role due to ill health. 
A trading update the firm said: 
We are pleased to have also announced today that Winston North will take up the position of group finance director and company secretary on 15 May. 
Winston has an excellent set of relevant skills and extensive experience gained during his time as divisional finance director within IMI plc and we look forward to his contribution to the business. 
The board would also like to thank Andrew Tonks for his work as interim finance director over the last few months and for his support in ensuring an orderly handover to Winston. Chief executive of Stadium Group, Charlie Peppiatt 8:41 Jonathon Manning Price cuts help push Morrisons sales up 3.4% 
Morrisons has reported better than expected sales growth in the first quarter after reaping the rewards of price cuts and strong Easter trading. 
The supermarket said like-for-like sales grew 3.4% in the three months to April 30, ahead of analyst expectations and an acceleration on the previous quarter’s 2.9%. 
Chief executive David Potts said: 
We are improving the shopping trip in many different ways, which is making Morrisons more popular and accessible for customers. 
These new initiatives in-store, online, in wholesale and services are beginning to build a broader, stronger Morrisons. 
The company said its Price Crunch initiative has seen more customers come through its doors, with sales over Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day and Easter particularly strong. 
Mr Potts said the group is “working hard” to remain competitive, despite an increase in the price of food imports linked to the collapse in the Brexit-hit pound. 
Morrisons said its deal to sell groceries through Amazon “continues to grow”, with the same-day and one-hour delivery service recently extended into more London postcodes. A Morrisons store (Photo: Mikael Buck/Morrisons/PA Wire) 8:33 Jonathon Manning Metrocentre and Eldon Square welcome top international names amid tough times in retail 
Metrocentre and Eldon Square owner Intu Properties is weathering tough times in retail, having already attracted a raft of top international names this year. 
Uncertainty surrounding Brexit and the rise of online shopping is serving up a challenging market for the high street, with several national firms already warning of difficult times ahead. 
Intu Properties, however, which owns intu Eldon Square in Newcastle and Gateshead’s intu Metrocentre among 17 centres in the UK and Spain, has released a trading update in which it says demand from tenants remains high, despite the fact that many retailers are being selective about their expansion plans. 
Directors said aspirational brands are continuing to recognise the attraction of destination shopping centres, with Hugo Boss and Guess joining the line up at intu Metrocentre, Tesla at intu Milton Keynes and Tag Heuer opening its first store in the West Midlands at intu Merry Hill. 
David Fischel, intu chief executive, said: 
Although retailers are being selective with their expansion plans, they are prioritising expansion to prime established locations with strong footfall. intu as the UK market leader with 17 prime centres is well positioned to take advantage of this demand. 
The environment for business this year is likely to be challenging with considerable uncertainty regarding the UK’s EU exit. However, it is our intention to deliver continuing growth in like-for-like net rental income. Entrance to Eldon Square from Northumberland Street (Photo: newcastle chronicle) 8:28 Jonathon Manning Business community pays tribute to Brian Manning of Esh Group 
Business and charity leaders have paid warm tributes to Brian Manning , the chief executive of construction and engineering firm Esh Group, who passed away last week. 
Mr Manning spent 44 years in the construction and engineering industry and earned a reputation as an astute businessmen who was also keen to put back something back into the local community, both personally and through his firm. 
A firm believer in inspiring young people, Mr Manning helped to create the Esh Academy two years ago, which trains up scores of apprentices every year. 
Esh’s commitment to the region was shown just a few days before Mr Manning’s death, when the company was shortlisted in the national Responsible Business Awards for its work promoting STEM subjects in schools. The company also sponsors the Newcastle Eagles basketball team. 
In a personal capacity, Mr Manning was vice president, board and council member of the North East England Chamber of Commerce, chairman of Durham Committee North East Chamber of Commerce as well as a board member of Changing Lives, Northumberland Arch, Business Durham and Castle View Enterprise Academy. 
Mr Manning, who lived in Sunderland, was also a member of the regional leadership team for Business in the Community and on the regional council of the CBI. 
James Ramsbotham, chief executive of the North East England Chamber of Commerce, knew Mr Manning for more than two decades and said that he became a firm friend as well as a colleague. 
He said: 
I have been privileged to have worked with Brian Manning in several guises over the last 25 years, first as his bank manager, then as a colleague within Esh Group, and latterly with him as vice president of the Chamber of Commerce. 
During all that time I have held him in the highest regard as a businessman and a friend, always dependable and usually right. 
He never shirked a challenge and imparted strength and determination to all those around him. The transformation from Lumsden and Carroll to the success of the Esh Group is the most phenomenal North East business success story and he has been at the heart of it throughout. 
But that alone does not begin to do justice to the colossus that was Brian Manning. His personal, commercial and charitable work with young people, with the homeless, with ex-offenders, with so many people from every part of the region has been both inspirational and life changing. 
If the definition of a civilised society is the way it takes care of its weakest citizens, Brian is without doubt one of the most civilised people I have ever met. 
He leaves an incredible legacy and so many people, many of whom never even knew him, owe him more than they will ever know. Brian Manning, chief executive of Esh Group (Photo: Esh Group) 8:23 KEY EVENT Disappointing first quarter for Next as sales plunge 
Retail giant Next revealed that high street sales plunged by 8.1% in its first quarter and cut its profit outlook once again as it warned that trading would remain under pressure. 
The worse-than-expected performance over the 13 weeks to April 29 came despite a boost from the later, warmer Easter this year, although Next said its Directory arm performed better, with sales up 3.3%. This left total full-price sales 3% lower. 
Next cut the top end of its profit guidance after the disappointing first quarter, with full-year profits now expected to fall by between 13.9% and 6.4%. 
Chief executive Lord Wolfson said the group was still battling to recover from mistakes made last year with its product ranges, while consumer confidence has also been hit as rising prices puts households under pressure. 
He said: 
There’s general pressure on the high street but the omissions in our own range are hitting our sales over and above any downturn. 
Lord Wolfson said he was expecting “more of the same” in the group’s second quarter, as it also comes up against tougher comparatives from a year earlier. He added: 
The clothing sector is not an easy sector and we recognised in our full-year results announcement in March that some of our ranges weren’t where we wanted them to be. 
The group admitted in March that its lines were missing the wardrobe staples Next is renowned for, such as easy-to-wear work blouses in a number of colours. 
It has since overhauled its ranges, but stressed the full impact of changes will not be seen for some months. 
We said that we expected some improvements from May onwards, but that our ranges would not be where we wanted them to be until the autumn season in September. We still believe this to be the case. 
Next said on Thursday. Next posted its first fall in annual profits for eight years in March, reporting a 3.8% fall in underlying pre-tax profits to £790.2m for the year to January. 
Its annual report last month revealed that Lord Wolfson saw his total pay packet plummet by more than 55% to £1.8m after the dire year. A Next store (Photo: Paul Faith/PA Wire) 8:16
